narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned new intro level programming
Python, object oriented programming, data structures, cryptography, deep recursion
I improved my Python skills.
I was able to practice my Python skills. I learned more about topics related to Python such as object orientated programming, SQL, etc.
I learned basic Python coding, SQL, unix commands, and data structures. In addition, I learned programming techniques and general problem solving techniques that are applicable in other STEM fields.
I learned a lot of CS Python concepts that I did not know previously
I learned a lot of Python, and hopefully many concepts important in all of computer science/coding.
I learned to effectively use the python programming language.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I thought this class was pretty good. The professor was ok at teaching
strengths: weekly psets that applied skills learned
Decent workload for a CS course, and the material taught was very interesting.
Strengths - psets were  great way to practice the topics we learned,

Strengths of the course: you learn a lot of Python concepts/ideas--PVM, OOP, deep recursion, SQL, list comprehension, decorators, exceptions, data bases
Weakness: the lectures can be unengaging and there is not a lot of interaction with other peers in the class.
The lectures could sometimes be confusing, but completing the weekly problem sets helped me really understand the material.
Very good at teaching python.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The class worked well online
Lectures were recorded.
You were not required to attend the lecture at the time of the live lecture which helped to provide flexibility
The virtual live sessions were effective, and the frequent office hours held by the instructor and TAs were also very helpful.

Professor Slade starts out each class with a logical problem of the day and also a bit later into the semester with a (usually Socratica) video related to the topic of the day, which were engaging and helped me to settle into the class, but he often plays them before class, so sometimes I don't see the entirety of the videos. The lectures are classical lectures that go through concepts that will be used on the problem sets, and can be unengaging, but he does ask if we have questions as we go over the concepts.

I watched most of the lectures after they took place because they were recorded and synchronous attendance was not required. I also revisited the recordings often when working on problem sets. For a class like this, I found that having recorded lectures was very helpful.
Zoom office hours with the TF's were amazing. They were easy to attend, and an integral part of my experience in this class. I could share my screen on Zoom and we could look at code together and break it down until I understood it well.
Recorded lectures and long office hours were incredibly helpful.
Virtual lecture is fine for learning over the internet. Probably better than in person actually.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes great way to get started with programming
Yes! Great intro course to Python
Yes - a great way to learn more Python for non-CS majors.
Yes I would, it is a great way to have a cursory overview of Python; learned useful concepts that can be applied to industry

Yes, I would recommend this course to any student who wants to learn basic programming skills, as Python is a very applicable and popular language. In addition, the courseload is moderate and the TAs provide helpful assistance.

While the lectures may be at times unengaging, this class serves as a good course to introduce students to many ideas of Python including PVM, OOP, deep recursion, SQL, list comprehension, decorators, exceptions, data bases, etc. The workload is reasonable and the problem sets are fun.

If you're interested in computer science and have some basic experience and just want to take one semester to stay sharp/learn a little, this is the perfect class. It doesn't count towards the CS major track, but if you're curious and want to learn for the sake of it, this will be a great experience.
Yes, if you want to learn Python and get a good foundation for computing knowledge.
Yes, if you want to learn python.
